Sales and Sales ManagementTraining Program 
This Program is designed to develop young college graduates for careers in life insurance sales and sales management. It provides an initial training period of 3 months (including 2 weeks at a Home Office School) before moving into full sales 
work. 
Those trainees who are interested in and who are found qualified for management responsibility are assured of ample opportunity to move on to such work in either our field offices or in the Home Office after an initial period in sales. 
Aggressive expansion plans provide unusual opportunities for those accepted. 
Arrange with the placement office for an interview with: 
HAROLD J. LEYES 

GENERAL AGENT 

SUITE 503 LASALLE WEST BUILDING o SOUTH BEND, IND. 
Call 233 -2 171

Yellow Pages 

OPERATING INSTRUCTIONS FOR CENTREX 
NOTRE DAME AND ST. MARY’S CAMPUS CALLS: Dial LAST four numerals. 
LOCAL CALLS: Dial “9” then the seven digit number. 
CAMPUS DIRECTORY ASSISTANCE: If not listed in directory -Dial “0”. 
ST. MARY’S DIRECTORY ASSISTANCE: Consult St. Mary’sDirectory -if not listed -Dial “0”. 
LOCAL DIRECTORY ASSISTANCE: Dial“9” -then 113. 
REPAIR AND ASSISTANCE: If your telephone is not working properly, or you need assistance with a call -Dial “0”. 
TO TRANSFER CALLS: 
Incoming calls ONLY may be transferred. Depress the re­ceiver hook 1 time and release; the operator will answer and you can give her your request. 
WHEN OFF CAMPUS DIALING CAMPUS NUMBERS: Dial ALL seven digits. If you do not know the number, dial the Notre Dame listed number -283-6011. 
LONG DISTANCE -DIRECT DISTANCE DIALING: 
Dial “9” 
Dial “1” 
Dial the area code Then dial the seven digit number. STUDENTS: 
GIVE THE OPERATOR YOUR SPECIAL BILLING NUMBER WHEN REQUESTED. ADMINISTRATIVE: 
GIVE THE OPERATOR THE NUMBER ASSIGNED TO YOU WHEN REQUESTED. 
TO REACH THE LONG DISTANCE OPERATOR: Dial “9” then “0”. 
CONFERENCE CALLS: 
Conference calls can be placed from any station on cam­pus by dialing “55” for the conference operator. It is possi­ble to have five conferees on one conference call. 
DIRECTORY CHANGES: 
Directory changes should be reported as they occur to Personnel Department. Changes include additions, deletions, number changes, corrections in Directory, etc. 
TO REPORT AN EMERGENCY: 
Dial “0” operator and give location of accident, name of injured person, if known, and extension of calling party. Calling party should stay on the line until the operator has made arrangements. 
Individuals in need of ambulance service for reason of ill­ness should contact a private ambulance. 
Suggested ambulances are: McGANN ........................................................................232-8076 HICKEY ........................................................................234-4155 
BILANCIO-GUISINGER ............................................ 291-5850 
SPECIAL INSTRUCTIONS TO STUDENTS 
Long Distance Collect calls incoming are not to be accepted from any source. A penalty of $5.00 willbe asses­sed by the University for each collect toll call accepted by a student. 
IN MAKING ANY CALL BE SURE TO WAIT FOR THE DIAL TONE. 
DIAL EACH DIGIT CAREFULLY

Fly home. Fly to Florida. Fly to New York. Fly to Los Angeles. Fly to Montreal. 

Make it a sure-thlng with Eastern Airlines’Youth Plan. You get a reserved seat at two-thirds fare. 
Now you can plan. Now you can let people know. 
Bye, bye, standby! 
Eastern can fly you to more than 100 cities. Atlanta, New York. 
Philadelphia, St. Louis, Houston, Montreal, Los Angeles, New Orleans, Seattle, Miami. 
YourTravel Agent or Eastern will make all the arrangements for you. 
Take a Vacation-Break. Eastern has a wide range of low cost vacations.And since you can plan ahead, there’re even easier to take. 
Florida You can spend a week in Fort 
Lauderdale...visit Miami or 
Miami Beach. 
The Bahamas Fly to Miami at two-thirds fare and for $38 more you can fly to Nassau round trip. Scuba. Great shopping. Night-clubbing “Over the hill.”

The 1969-70 skating season wiU run from September 22 to May 15, 1970. Season tickets wiU enable holders to all General public sessions during this period, but not the Summer Session. There wiUbe occasional conflicts due to Hockeygames plus certain ACC conventions or shows. The Ice Facility is available for rentalfor parties at the above-mentioned times for $25.00 per hour.

Events in the MONOGRAM ROOM AND MEETING ROOMS do not restrict utilization of any other area of the building. The only restriction wouldbe a restriction of traffic in and about the area of the Monogram Room and MeetingRooms. 
Events in the CONCOURSE do not restrict utilization of any other area of the building. The only restriction wouldbe arestriction of traffic in and about the area of the Concourse. 
Events in the AUXILIARY GYM do not restrict utilization of any other area of the building. The only restriction would be a restriction of traffic in and about the area of the Auxiliary Gym. 
Events in the FENCING GYMdo not restrict utilization of any other area of the building. The only restriction wouldbe a restriction of traffic in and about the area of the Fencing Gym.

ARTGALLERYUMVERSITYOFNOTREDAME
ART 

69-70 CALENDAR 
August 31 to November 2, 1969 
All The Sculpture From The Permanent Collection:For the first time the Art Gallery will exhibit its entire collection of sculpture. With over 500 pieces in the Permanent Collection, nearly every sculptural tradition will be represented in this 
exhibition of plastic form. (East Gallery) 
September 14 to October 26, 1969 
Thomas S. Fern: An exhibition of recent works by the Chair­man of the Department of Art, Dr. Thomas S Fern. It will be a group of experimental works done with acrylic and styrofoam that explore the order of sym metry and three dimensional form. A group of drawings by Fern will also be shown. (East Gallery) 
October 5 to November 30, 1969 
The Joseph H. Hazen Collection: The Advisory Council arranged for the loan of this widely known collection which is presently housed in the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University. Dating from the early 20th century to 1969, the collection features works by Metzinger, De Kooning, Hartung, Soulages, Motherwell, Hofmann, and Jackson Pol­lack. (W est Gallery) 
October 12 to November 8, 1969 
The Lithographs of Sam Francis: Spontaneous patterns and bright colors characterize this selection of lithographs by the contemporary Californian, Sam Francis. The artist has ex­hibited widely, his works appearing in major exhibitions in England, France, Belgium, Switzerland, Japan, South America and the United States. The Pasadena Art Museum has made this exhibition possible. (East Gallery) 
November 2, 1969 to February 8, 1970 
The Sense of Form In Art: Many artists through the centuries have wished to create in paintings the illusion of a third dimension, the suggestion of space, depth and volume on the flat surface. Such writers as Bernard Berenson referred to this illusion simply as "form." This exhibition will bring out the development of this illusion as It was achieved by Flemish, Italian and French painters. Examples of so called "flat paint­ings" will be shown "to point up the contrast. (East Gallery) 
November 23, 1969 to February 8, 1970 Conservation at Notre Dam e: An active program for the propercare of the paintings and sculpture in our Permanent Col lection has been maintained during the past 12 years. To bring out the meaning of this program and some of the reeuHs," this exhibition Is being put together with the help and^-advice of our Conservator, Mr. Alfred Jakstas, and his associates. (East Gallery) December 7. 1969 to February 15, 1970 

The German Expressionists and Their Contemporaries: Se­lected from many private and public collections, these paint­ings, graphics and sculpture will offer a broad view of the art of the early 20th century in Germany. A variety of styles 
will be noted from Beckmann to Schmidt-Rottluff. from Klee to Kandinsky. (West Gallery) 
February 22 to April 12, 1970 

The Age of Vasari: Over 60 museums and collectors from the United States and Europe will contribute to this exhibi­tion of sixteenth century Italian Art. Works by Giorgio Vasari, artist-blographer, and his contem poraries will enable the viewer to investigate the unique stylistic characteristics of 
the Mannerist phenomenon. The exhibition has been organized with the State University of New York at Binghamton and will occupy all five galleries. (West Gallery) 
April 14 to May 11, 1970 

Folk Art In America: Folk art in America starts with the earliest colonies People wanted to add something to their lives beyond bare necessities Folk art would be the work of a limner, or someone with very little academic training, th e limner might be a traveling artist or a village artist. The distinction between art and craft meant little to the folk artist. (East Gallery) 
April 19 to May 7, 1970 

Contemporary Arts Festival: Student interest in the Contem­porary world will be demonstrated in this exhibition arranged and sponsored by the Contemporary Arts Festival. Creativity dominates in this collaborative effort of student and artist. (East Gallery) 
April 25 to July 1, 1970 

Stanley S. Sessler in Retrospect: The creative work of Stanley Sessler at Notre Dame will be featured in this exhibition of paintings, pastels and drawings. Chairman of the Art Depart­ment from 1937 to 1960, Mr. Sessler has taught several thousand students. This exhibition will com mem orate 40 years of devoted service to the University and inspiration to his students. (West Gallery) 
May 10 to June 7, 1970 Student Exhibition: Tfiis year's best examples of work by undergraduate and graduate students in the Department of Art at the University. The show reveals a good cross section of the experiment and style factors in contemporary art as they influence the students in the studios. (East Gallery) 
rsnaugiHiessy hail own 10to 5 daw • weekends 1to 5 
REV. ANTHONY J. LAUCK, C.S.C., Director DEAN A. PORTER. Curator DON VOGL, Designer 
RICHARD-RAYMOND ALASKO, Special Asst, to the Curator 
FREDERICK GEISSEL, Preparator

GERMAN EXPRESSIONISTS WITH EM­PHASIS ON KIRCHNER by Patricia Boyd Wilson. 
GERMAN EXPRESSIONISM AS RELI­GIOUS EXPERIENCE byDr.EmstScheyer. Department of Art History, Wayne State 
University, Detroit, Michigan. 
March 1970 
SPECULATIONS ABOUT EARLY FLOR­ENTINE MANNERISM by Irving L Zup­nkk. Professor of Art History, State Uni­versity of New York at Binohamton-
GfORGIO VASARI AND THE SALA GRANDE IN THE PALAZZO VECCHIO by Edm uxl Plllabury, Assistant Curator, National Gallery, Washington*,D,C. 
FEDERIGO ZUCCARO S SKETCHBOOK OF THE LIFE OF TADDEO ZUCCARO by Janos Scholz, Musician, Collector of Italian drawings. Lecturer. 
THE IMPLICATIONS OF DISEGNO FOR MANIERA PAINTING by Maurice Poirier, Graduate student. New York University and Samuel H. Kress Fellow. 
THE MANNERED IMAGE" 16th CEN­TURY MEDALLIONS by Richard Ray­mond Alaako, Director, Art Gallery, St. Mary's College. 
THE AGE OF VASARI. THE FiGURA SERPENTiNATA: MANNERIST SCULP­TURE" STYLISTIC SIGNIFICANCE OF 16th CENTURY, GRAPHICS by Dean A. Porter, Assistant Professor of Art His­tory, and Curator? U al#& ity of Notre flam e.

Arthur Frommer’s $5-a-day Travel Guides! Only$2.50 each. 
Actually save money while traveling to the world’s most fasci­nating places! Inside tips from this renowned expert in budget travel show you how to get more from your money while seeing the most...including places many travelers miss. Discover where to go...what to see...how much to pay... from these virtual encyclopedias of vacation information. They include maps, transportation, menus, capsule language vocabularies, bargain shopping and rules on tipping. 
Plan now. Choose any of .these guides today and travel like an insider tomorrow!

From m er's 
1969 
Europe on $5-a-Day—the “bible” of experienced travelers. Planning to see Europe soon? Read this bookbefore you do.. .take it withyou. An all-time best-seller, it popularized low-cost luxury travel. This year’s edition has a new, special $10-a-day supplement for those who want to spend a little more. Its chapter on inexpensive auto rentals is a do-not-miss. 
These other $5-a-Day guides take you around the world for mini-money. Find out how inexpensive traveling can be to Scandinavia...Greece and Yugoslavia . . . Spain . . . England . . Ireland . . . India :. .Mexico ... SouthAmerica ...and inside the States to New York City . ... Washington, D. C. .. .the West Coast... Hawaii. Candid comments that are worth a million for only.$2.50! New this year —India opens up the fascinating Far East to the low-bu'dget traveler. 
Arthur Frommer’s European Almanac—facts you’ll be glad you knew. A fact-filled companion to anyof the $5-a-Day books on Europe. 10 books under" one cover: facts about 18 countries... 49 maps of 27 cities...tours of major cities...discount train plans... menu translation... extensive vocabulary guides...and indispensable glossary of hard-to­find information like road signs, clothing sizes and mileage between main roads. 

Dollar-wise guides for the traveler with a little more to spend. These guides to England, Italy and now the South Pacific cover the most value for your money regardless of price range, but focus sharply on medium priced range hotels, restau­rants, nightspots, tours, shopping and other facili- ‘ ties. Special attention is given to little known but interesting places in each country. 
It’s never too early to plan low-cost travel! Start now to make your dollar go farther. Let Arthur Frommer show you how. Check your choice of travel guides below, detach and mail coupon with pay­ment today. College Directory, c/o Frommer/Pasmantier Publishing Corp., 70 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10011
